climbs.name: Uncle Kentucky
climbs.fa: FA: Joel Unema EB: Mat Greco

content.description: Incredible thin and technical moves on quality sandstone define this climb.  While less steep than the lines in the Barrel, Uncle Kentucky packs a lot of difficult and unique movement into its moderate height.
content.protection: The start of this route is scoured out by water, require a log start.  Climb the log at the base to reach the first crimp rail a few feet below and left of the first draw and climb up from there!   6ish bolts to chain anchor
content.location: Across from Lil' Red and Big Green.

content.description: The first line bolted at this area of James Canyon and classic.  Climb pockets and edges, traversing left inside the Barrel.  Make a big move to ample holds and continue through the super-steep to the chains!
content.location: This is the right-most route in the Barrel, the steep feature on the right side of the canyon.

content.description: Hidden in the largest corridor.  Climb inner face on dark patina rock.
content.location: Main corridor to climbers right of uncle kentucky

content.description: The direct line up the headwall. Prepare for perfect two finger pocket pulling. Crank on pockets then edges to same two bolt finish of Lil red.

A colorful route with neat holds and a unique crux. Stick clip the high first bolt, and start from the same rock stack as Uncle Kentucky. Traverse left across crimps, and do a few powerful moves to get situated on the arete. The crux is around bolt 3, and involves a long move to a jug complex, with a few miserable holds on the way that may or may not be useful. After this, you get a few bolts of hero climbing on jugs.
content.location: Left of Uncle Kentucky, but shares the same start. Stick clip is mandatory.

content.description:
James Canyon is a beautiful slot canyon cut into the Coconino Sandstone.  Often traveled as a canyoneering route or off-path hike, this hidden canyon offers high-quality sandstone in an incredible and serene setting.  Edges, pockets, and jugs, in multi-colored steep and sculpted sandstone bring to mind the Red River Gorge and led to the nickname "Little Kentucky" for this crag.     Old anchors on at least one crack show some development prior to this year, but the climbing included here was developed by John Gould, John Crawley, David Bloom, and Mat Greco during the summer of 2013.  This crag is incredibly cool and may provide the perfect escape from the heat of May and June.  Conditions are prime from May through October, except during monsoons, when the sandstone may become saturated.  Light rains will leave the climbs untouched, as the rock is quite steep.   

  GPS coordinates are estimated.
